awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Active Learning Integrated Nuclear Engineering Education (ALINE)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue science, technology, engineering or mathematics (STEM) graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Alabama A&M University seeks to improve undergraduate students' preparation and success towards a career in nuclear engineering or an advanced degree by focusing on active learning strategies. Undergraduate students are involved in the project as researchers. 

This project has the objectives to: enhance student learning and technical skills by integrating active learning units into nuclear engineering courses; study the efficacy of the active learning model and units on nuclear engineering skill-set development; and improve retention and graduation rates in nuclear engineering programs, thus increasing the participation of women and underrepresented minorities in the nuclear engineering workforce. This project is guided by formative and summative evaluation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Alabama A&M University received a $400,000 Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) award in 2018 titled "Targeted Infusion Project: Active Learning Integrated Nuclear Engineering Education (ALINE)". The goal of the ALINE project was to enhance student learning and strengthen STEM education in nuclear engineering areas at Alabama A&M University. The active learning units in classes and the mentoring and research activities helped to improve undergraduate students' preparation and success toward a career in nuclear engineering. The project also prepared undergraduates to pursue graduate degrees in STEM fields.

ALINE enhanced the STEM pipeline through the improvement of retention and graduation rates in nuclear engineering programs at Alabama A&M University and increased the participation of women and underrepresented minorities in the United States nuclear workforce. Data on a cohort of eight students over a two-year period showed improvement in their average cumulative GPA from 3.37 in the entry semester to 3.40, 3.41, 3.45, and 3.48 consecutively in the next four semesters.

The problem-solving and hands-on laboratory active-learning units that were developed provided infrastructure for teaching, technical training of students, and research activities in nuclear engineering. The project provided laboratory instruments that will continue to support engineering senior design projects in semiconductor nuclear detector fabrication and instrumentation. The instruments and equipment installed as part of the hands-on laboratory active-learning units provided and will continue to provide infrastructure for research in nuclear engineering, physics, chemistry, materials science, electrical engineering, and mechanical engineering fields. The ALINE project has enhanced the curriculum for the Nuclear Power concentration of the B.S. in Electrical Engineering and the Nuclear Systems concentration of the B.S. in Mechanical Engineering program at Alabama A&M University.

The professional development and training activities of the ALINE project were carried out through collaborations with Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL). These include one-week BNL hands-on training and workshops in the fall and spring semesters and research training during summer internships at BNL. These activities also provided training in technical writing and engaged students in professional development activities. These activities impacted the nuclear engineering students in skills that are critical to the nuclear industry and thus benefited the United States? nuclear workforce. Most of the graduates from the nuclear engineering concentrations gained employment with nuclear industries and the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC). This project also enhanced university-industry collaborations through internships and co-ops at industries and U.S. Department of Energy national laboratories.


Last Modified: 08/31/2023
Modified by: Stephen Egarievwe
